newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: South Korean court sentences 39 more students.
newsitem.headline: South Korean court sentences 39 more students.

text.p: A South Korean court on Monday jailed 16 students and gave suspended prison terms to 23 others for taking part in violent pro-North Korean campus protests in August, court officials said.
It was the third mass sentencing in a week in connection with the unrest at Seoul's Yonsei University during which a riot policeman died.

On Monday, the sixteen students were jailed for between 10 months and 2-1/2 years for taking part in an illegal protest, engaging in acts of violence and obstructing police in their duty, the officials said.
The criminal court gave suspended sentences to another 23.
Since Tuesday last week, a total of 189 students have been sentenced in a crackdown on a leftist student movement. A further 255 students are standing trial for their part in Yonsei protests.

The pro-democracy student campaign backed President Kim Young-sam's rise to power, but authorities say activists have been influenced by North Korea and posed threats to national security since Kim implemented Western-style democracy.
A total of 85 students have now been jailed for up to three years and more than 100 have their sentences suspended.
Presiding judge Park Byong-mook told the court on Monday the Yonsei protests had "given enormous shocks to the people with (their) pro-North Korean nature and violence."
Park said the sentences were a warning against violence.

In August, riot police stormed Yonsei to end the seven-day occupation of two teaching blocks by students who were taking part in an annual pro-Korean unification rally and calling for the withdrawal of 37,000 U.S. troops stationed in South Korea.
One riot policeman died in pitched fighting during which students used petrol bombs, iron pipes and stones.

Seoul maintains it is committed to unification, but authorities accused the students of embracing North Korea's plan to leave intact both Pyongyang's communist system and Seoul's democratic government.

Police produced stacks of North Korean propaganda that they said had been seized from the students. North and South Korea are still technically at war since the 1950-53 Korean conflict was ended by a truce, not a ceasefire.
On Friday, a London-based human rights group, Amnesty International, accused the Seoul government of widespread human rights abuses after riot police raided Yonsei.
"Police in South Korea were responsible for widepread and systematic ill-treatment after the students were arrested," Amnesty said in a report.

It also accused South Korean police of sexually assaulting arrested female students. "Female students said that police had grabbed their breasts and other parts of their bodies and shouted sexual insults."
Almost 6,000 students were detained after the worst campus unrest since President Kim took power in 1993.
Subsequent efforts to stamp out left-wing ideology had led to an alarming rise in the number of political prisoners, it said.
